UUID extension uuid
&reftitle.intro;
The UUID extension provides functions to teal with Universally Unique IDentifiers as defined by the Open Software Foundation (OSF) for the Distributed Computing Environment (DCE).
An UUID is 16 bytes (128 bits) long, which gives approximately 3.4x10^38 unique values (there are approximately 10^80 elemntary particles in the universe according to Carl Sagan's Cosmos). The new UUID can reasonably be considered unique among all UUIDs created on the local system, and among UUIDs created on other systems in the past and in the future.
UUIDs may be created using the systems MAC address, a timestamp with nano second resolution and a sequence counter or by using 128 bit random values. The former are guaranteed to be unique but may lead to privacy problems while the later are not 100% guaranteed to be unique but can reasonably considered to be so (unless a poor random generator is used).
The library used by this extension generates random UUIDs if a high-quality source for random numbers (like /dev/urandom) is available, else it falls back to unsing the systems current time and MAC address by default. It is possible to override the default behaviour by specifying which type of UUID to generate.
